com:
Why You Should Copy Anime:
https://i.imgur.com/zNDsyF0.jpg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbKqIJcIUCw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgjx6y6B_G8

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

Recommended Resources:
https://pastebin.com/Yz2scAEc

/mmg/ - Manga Making General:
>>>/ic/mmg

com:
I personally think that anime is overrated. Western cartoons are so much better. Anime is usually really weird and pervy as well as having plenty of Japanese beliefs and traditions that don't make sense to Westerners. For example, characters taking baths together or using stupid honorifics. I've also looked at Pixiv and it seems that Japanese artists can only draw in one artstyle.
I'm planning on becoming an animator in the future and I'm afraid about what my audience will think if it's ever discovered that I hate anime. I will probably just try to avoid questions such as "What do you think of anime?" or "What is your favorite anime", but when you are an animator or just an artist in general, it's impossible to completely avoid questions regarding anime. What do you guys think?

The big reason why animation fans are fans of almost exclusively anime right now is because western animation of that caliber has been fucking absent, man. And anime has a broader range of subject matter than western animation right now, that also matters a great deal.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:

Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

Why you should not trust youtube shills:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Twy5Wo8m284

If you have any additional questions, ask them.
Remember to ignore all chinese shills.

>I'm thinking of getting the Wacom One, should I buy it?
Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. Check out the webm to understand how bad they are. Also watch out, Chinese companies shill HARD on /ic/; they do a lot of samefagging and frequently hurl personal insults.

>Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

>>6405586
There's a fundamental dilemma that gonna rise in the next decade. Is this specific kind of AI really needed?

Up until now we had mostly mechanical and eletronic machines and also task focused softwares that we built and controlled, all of them created new fields to explore and specialize, but this new AIs are able to learn what we do, so the replacement cycle could be so steep that there won't be anything left for us.

Think about it, AI could be extensively used fragmented in minor, specialized tasks, for instance, an art program could make the already existing tools way better, such as bucket tool, masking, lasso, color gradients, smart brushes. I'm not a coder, but I'm certain there could be tasks for an AI to help them instead of doing the WHOLE thing, like checking errors and maybe even suggesting ways to correct it?

NTA but
>detail
>finished/more effort
That's not what the difference between the two is, or at least not the true difference. You're only seeing the surface level. The real differences here are

1.) A far better understanding of form. The face on the right is the most striking example, the way that the eyes are drawn indicates the head as a rounded volume with mass, whereas the left is a flat shape with sticker eyes applied to it. The jacket, clothes and even hair made of distinct, solid masses overlaid upon and wrapping around the body in layers. They all feel like they have weight and force applied to them as well. If you were really paying attention, you'll also notice very subtle indicators implying forms like the bones and tendons of the hand and the wrist under the skin- like the clothes, there is a feeling of the skin stretched upon and wrapping around these delicate forms.

2.) Better understanding of subject matter. Not only does the artist have a better understanding of human anatomy, they have an understanding of the anatomy of EVERYTHING in the piece. The jacket, the shirt, the pants, the hair, the skin and bone, they know the parts, the materials, how they fit together, and most importantly WHY that they are the way they are and act the way they do. This is why the clothes, the hair, the skin have such definite mass and purposeful application of forces upon them. See those crisp, chunky folds in the jacket on the right and compare them to the almost vacuum sealed, skintight jacket on the left with muddy indefinite marks indicating the idea of wrinkles that the artist knows should be there but doesn't understand how they work as 3D form, or the properties of the material that they're deforming.

name: Anonymous
com: How can I draw well like the old masters?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6403573
Decide which masters you want to emulate. Make a list. Then, learn about the mediums and the methods they used and start creating master copies. Don’t just try to reproduce the final image from scratch. If they sketched first, then did a base layer of shadows, etc., then do the same. If they used a combination of charcoal and white chalk on colored paper, do that instead of trying to produce the same thing by working with a single color on light paper. And try to work at a similar scale. If things are coming out badly, stop, trace the image, then try again.

Simultaneously, start drawing from life as much as possible. There are multiple ways to draw from life and you should choose a method. Sight size method is one and comparative method is another. Pick one, learn about it, and stick to it for a while. While you are starting to learn, it’s a good idea to limit yourself to a single light source and a limited color palette. Work in a dark room with one lamp behind you so you can see your paper.

Also, a great resource is the Charles Bargue Drawing Course. That was used by most students after 1875 and is still taught in many ateliers. Really helped me.

com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

>>6404987
to clarify
i wasn't talking about watercolor. i meant that even for drawings in dry media i only use pure cotton paper, (but not watercolor cotton paper.) if you explain to buyers of watercolor that something is made of cotton, that's simply expected, especially if the buyer has been in the market for buying watercolor works.
i go beyond what is expected when it comes to materials. for oil painting, the standard is simply to use tube paints, with titanium as the white, over acrylic gesso. i grind from dry pigments, use the best lead white available, and use lead oil ground with the same lead white.
it's not merely an issue of the work fading or deteriorating in 10 years or in their lifetime either. as there are practices and materials that i admit are more archival, but are simply not as beautiful, prestigious, or expensive. aluminum panels, mdf, and plywood are very stable, but are not as inspiring as a joined solid wood panel with hand cut butterfly keys. when it comes to works of art, i consider the support as part of the art, so they must be beautiful as well.
or some materials might outlast others in a few hundred years, but the more available materials are good enough.

Thank you so much anon, you're right - the pose is incredibly stiff. I did this over a year ago but I'm back into art and wanting to fix my shit. How do I improve stiff poses for the future, and how do I draw the legs and feet?

Any books you can recommend?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6405105
You had the beginnings of contrapasto but didn't seem to know what to do with it- shoulders and hips pointing opposite eachother (up/down)

Honestly when I was trying to get more fluid poses, I did a lot of gesture of moving people- video, from still images of dancers and athletes.

I honestly haven't looked at a ton of the classic books here specifically for posing- more for polishing my fundies and understanding forms.

Image reference is your friend, don't run away from it.

As far as off the cuff making poses less stiff, I'll sometimes do warmups where i draw the whole torso as a bean, then just add the rest and shape the torso.

Remember though, if your character is sitting and leaning over, unless they're putting their all into intentionally posing, their back hunches over, not divots in for sex appeal. I notice that's a thing a lot of beginners don't often think of.

I think it's weirdly labeled.
>Blue ("Shadow Edge") is cast shadows
>Red ("Boundary line between light and shadow") is ambient occlusion.
Now that I look at it again, I think it's a strange translation. "Boundary line between light and shadow" is a very long way of saying "penumbra"

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6404781
>https://warosu.org/ic/thread/S4578220#p4578324
This is the same concept in different verbiage. The shadow shape on a complex object is often a combination of form shadow and cast shadow edges. A form shadow is created by surfaces turning away from the light. The cast shadow is the shadow cast on a surface by another. Generally speaking and in particular regard to figure painting, the form shadow edge is almost always softer than the cast shadow edge. So if you want to make your shadow shapes look realistic, you need to include these variances.

>>6404907
>It is entirely possible to become great at drawing from observation and be completely bereft at inventing figures and scenes from imagination. In fact, it is a common pitfall.

Strong take. I'll just point out that observation development follows a U shape and a lot of "great at drawing from observation" people end up sitting at the bottom of it because it's comforting, joyful to draw, and does not require much attention/energy to get something that is passably accurate. This is your atelier student who is just good enough to fool themselves and the audience but has gotten complacent. The right hand side that spikes back up requires dialing in all of your knowledge of fundies to re-start your education and now really push beyond mere observation. It is very arduous to disregard what you think you know and begin over, but some people are called to it. This is what filters out a lot of people from reaching the levels of Mønsted or Shishkin.

>>6404811
Your activity is a factor. Many children beg accounts get thousands of followers because they are composed of other children. Kids are easily exciteable and love spamming comments everywhere and sharing almost anything they come across which is activity, and instagram likes activity. They also do a lot of follow-for-follow and engage with each other all the time, spreading themselves through word of mouth. That's why you may see some garbage accounts with a lot of followers. You can do it too, but it may not bring the most healthy audience.

Another thing is just trends, really. You just have to get in on the new thing early and you're bound to get some recognition sooner or later depending on luck. There are also artists that started elsewhere and garnered following from other socials like twitter. Many artists have a lot of socials and the little reach they get on all of them kind of adds up in the end.

Lastly, if you just post what you draw and wait for a return, it's very unlikely to get anywhere unless you're a gigaluckchad and algorithm blesses you. You'll need to put in some work in advertising yourself and getting your name out there either by interacting with other users/artists, or you can join some art contests, draw trends and challenges.

>>6404899
Op listen, I’ve been where you are. It doesn’t mean anything. What you’re experiencing is years of putting aside interests in favor of study. This happens to every artist. Now that you have attained the skills, it’s time to reconnect with the things that you love - why you got into art in the first place.

To do this, it will require introspection, not web surfing. I can’t tell you what drives you. You need to figure that out on your own. And once you get a lead, start accumulating inspiration. Get a Pinterest account and start collecting those things that spark excitement within. It can come from many odd places, perhaps it’s a particular processs that excites you, or maybe it’s color palettes, simplistic or complicated art styles, creating comics to bring characters to life or maybe just fun shape design. It can be one or many of such things but you need to find out what they are and start pursuing them.

Find out what aesthetics you like, collect examples of them, and then copy those examples until you can do something similar. This is how your work will start feeling satisfying and meaningful. Reconnect with what you love, it’s the only way to experience love for what you do.

last_replies.com:
Take a blank piece of paper, and with a pencil, scribble on it for 3 seconds. Then with a pen,try turning part of the scribble into something that the random shapes suggest to you.

And as test for yourself, attempt a larger work,and do the required homework. That being approaching the project piecemeal,thinking of the scene and working out how the characters are interacting with each other. Compose on very cheap paper very quickly, rough sketches to place people and props,and the angles of view involved. Then you design the elements of the picture. In sketchbooks, taking your time to be experimental. Then,once you are happy with your final pictures, you can refer to them as you lay out the penultimate work. In this one,Ihad to think about what these Magmamen were like,and the final result is only serviceable, but the 5 previous attempts in my research sketchbook were far worse. Remember that you have no time restraints, so taking the time to try new things is now. Even Davinci liked to draw bits of things.

name: Anonymous
com:
Hey, guys. Can anyone here tell me how to properly choose colors when shading. My current method of shading is that I usually paint black on Overlay layers with different opacity, constantly switching until I find one that I think is right but usually that method is very time consuming due to how I need to constantly switch around multiple layers. Plus, my art would sometimes look plastic like from the colors.
Is there a guide I could use so that I can find the perfect color to shade and make it look less waxy.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I usually go inch warmer and more saturated and maybe bit more darker than the base color. For skin I make another round of shading with even more red to give that vibrant touch

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6400309
not quite. instead of finding "shading you like", find a "picture you like" and then analyze how the shading and light in that picture relate to the colors of the things in the picture.
are the shadows more saturated? shifted more red/blue/whatever? what is the light situation around them? is it night? something like that.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6398576
First of all I hope you are doing well anon
Second, Sorry about the armor, I know you were going for a more "cell shaded" look but you can still simplify this example

So lets start with this, NEVER SHADE WITH BLACK! if you are going the Overlay method go with dark blue, red, purple or green
If you wanna shade something directly remember that Regular whites are boring, always tint whites slightly with yellow or cyan, or any color for that matter
When you pick a darker color for the shadow, don't just drag the slider to black and call it a day, hue shift towards a cooler color
also this is already told by the other anons but here it is again, look up your favorite artists, color pick:
-the base color
-The shadow color
compare the two and see how you did he pick the shadow color, did he lower the satuaration of the color? maybe only hue shifted it towards blue and made it slightly darker?
Also look up how different materials react to light, learn proper shadow placement, sometimes shadows arent just darker versions of the regular color, maybe ambient light from the background is bouncing on it
Pinterest has a shit ton of refs and tutorials about shading, and the website's algorithm will help you find artists that have elements of your targeted artstyle
Check out:
- Speedo
- Alex Ahad
- Dreamin'
- KAINONAUT

They have colorful and interesting formulas, if you wanna do it your way, study real light and exaggerate it

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Okay, tried incorporating the eyedropper method while trying to mimic Alex Ahad's shading. What do you think?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6403522
first off, i'm not sure what you mean by eyedropper method so i hope you didn't just pick colours and dropped them on your canvas because that would be completely missing what i said. but colour-wise, it already looks much better. if it were me, i'd push the values even more, but thats for you to experiment with.
overall, i think you should keep what you learnt, and now focus on getting better shapes in your characters first. As i see it, while you now already have learned to choose better colours, you don't really know where to put them, because your characters are symbol drawn and therefore don't really have depth and therefore nowhere for shadows to fall in the first place.
since i assume you're pretty young, i don't really know what would be the best way to fix that, though. figure drawing is always a good start, or copying some images you like while trying to comprehend them as geometry, and not just the resulting flat plane.
either way, good luck!

com: What's the secret of good lineart?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6400634
Round brush, 100% opacity.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Man no wonder this board is dying, people can't be bother to give any actual advice.

Some general rules are:

-Don't be afraid to erase and do the same line over and over until it looks good

-Digitally, work with multiple layers for new stroke, so that when overlapping, you can erase easily

-Move around the canvas/paper you're using so that your wrist can glide up and down naturally

-Use thicker lines on the outside, and thinners ones for details.

This is basic advice, I suggest you try replicate 1:1 some mangaka's work you appreciate. Maybe pick something that isn't tone-heavy so you can really focus on their linework.

Naoki Saito has a few good videos about line, while it isn't the focus of his work his insight is still useful, he also works screenless:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IIwzDISTrTM

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CYCAHkorpc0

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=abftOwHsc6g

>>6401314
It does. Screenless gives you more friction and you can use a paper over it's surface to get a trad feel. Paper grain is nature's stabilizer.

You want good lineart? Literally just find good artwork, reduce the opacity, trace it until you're good, analyze why there are thick lines and thin lines, also do a lot of drills, straight lines, circles, S and C lines, etc...

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6403472

>Sure, ctrl+Z but I think OP is more asking about knowledge on what makes good line work

And I'm giving him a method to make good linework with the style of the shit he posted. He's literally asking for advice for how to do it.

>A new layer for each stroke? lol

When you're working on places where strokes easily overlap, such as complex strands of hair, yes. CSP has a function that negates the need for this with the vector erasers, but you'll need to work with vector layers, and they're too finnicky. It's annoying, but it speeds up the process in the long-term. I believe ctrl+paint also talks about this in one of his videos. Less time cleaning, more time drawing.

>Not really that important in digital as there's zoom and canvas rotation.

Beginners don't rotate their canvas, period. It's not something people pick up on naturally like in trad, as most use screenless tablets and it requires more effort to rotate the canvas than it would a real piece of paper.

>That is just one of many methods for use of line weight

Yes, the one used in the pic he posted, which I assume is what he wants to aim for. That's also the reason why I said to study from mangaka's work. Everyone has their own take and flavor on line work.

How do you develop an art practice/vision? How do you even get one in the first place?

This artist is influenced by Freud and Rego. Should we look to the established artists first, and then adapt their work/riff of them in some way?

This artist is so young and yet she's light years ahead of me with her art/ideas. Depressing!

https://www.lorenaleviart.net/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6400372
The question of finding a 'unique vision' is, in my opinion, not helpful. It's an artifact of western fine arts abandoning any notion of a canon or craft to pursue sheer novelty (ending, finally, in banana-taped-to-wall type art, that is all "vision", with no skill or craft).

Not that the unique vision of an artist does not exist, but it's something cultivated over years of work and problem solving, rather than pursued as an end unto itself. Think of a football player who gets so wrapped up in striking a dramatic pose for the cameras that he is distracted and preoccupied at the moment of throwing the ball.

Not sure what can be done about it; self conscious efforts to revive old craft technique are usually only partial successes.

but overall i agree, it's usually developed, and a person with a developed art sensibility usually envisions more complex/interesting things in general

Yeah, Freud's work is great, and you can tell just how much more focused and coherent his style is. He actually knows how to draw, and he's trying to create something which is legitimately aesthetically pleasing - his distortions all fit together. His treatment of skin in particular is fantastic.
As you mentioned, it's funny that OP lauds Lorena's work as being inventive/sophisticated in her vision, when the only parts of her work with merit are shoddy imitations of Freud's style.

>>6400684
the metaphor has been used since ancient times, through related concepts like invention, genius, inspiration, and even divine madness.
the problem is that the concept is right now so thoroughly married to the modernist understanding on what it means to be creative. for example we often hear phrases like "going beyond realism" which use of language guides contemporary artist on how one should create art. as if the end of art throughout history was primarily the recreation of the visible world on a painted support until modernists came. of course the easiest and most predictable way of "going beyond realism" is through conspicuous abstraction, being nonsensical, or showing the process or manner in which a work was painted. Gimmicks.
i also think artists today don't really believe in their works. not in the same way that michelangelo believed in the justness of his art. it's just their "thing." so it doesn't matter, as long as it stands out. to truly believe in what you are doing beyond simply it meaning something to you personally or being interesting to you, in some sense means rejecting other ways as inferior, yet we are supposed to be accepting of many things in our modern society.
